description: Borrowed from Spanish and Portuguese negro (“black”), from Latin nigrum (“shiny black”), of uncertain origin, but possibly from Proto-Indo-European *negʷ- (“bare; night”). Doublet of noir.

entries.meaning: (dated, offensive) Relating to a black ethnicity.
(dated, now offensive) Black or dark brown in color.
(dated, now offensive) A person of Black African ancestry.
examples: The negroes believe that its presence has a sanitary effect upon their cattle  […]
